posts.name: Electra Lucky Norwood
posts.cooked:
Introducing: The Stellar Controller

Check out how we did it! (This is an ongoing project, this document will be updated as it progresses.)

The Stellar Controller was developed by Stellar Robotics students and mentors to improve our robot’s performance after learning swerve drive in the 2023 off-season. We found that standard Xbox or flight stick controllers lacked the features our drivers needed and were costly. RC hobbyists, professionals, and BattleBots teams use controllers with multiple inputs (switches, scroll wheels, latching push buttons, etc.), which are hard to find on game controllers. While some RC radios can connect to computers for simulators, they are much more expensive due to added wireless hardware. Additionally, FRC and other robotics competitions often prohibit such controls. And thus, the Stellar Controller was born.

Iteration #1 The first iteration of the controller garnered a lot of attention and gained us the Innovation in Control Award at the Buckeye Regional in 2024. This inspired us to improve it, and eventually release a whitepaper on it with how many teams were interested in making their own. stellar controller 1 918×516 119 KB

stellar controller 1 918×516 119 KB

stellar controller 1 918×516 119 KB

Iteration #2 The following year, we unveiled our newest design of the controller, and achieved the Creativity Award at the Greater Pittsburgh Regional in 2025! We had so many teams asking us about it, that we decided to make this post before we attended Buckeye this week to show off how we did it and see what the community thinks. Check out the latest we will be using at Buckeye this year: stellar controller 2 front 918×516 84.9 KB stellar controller 2 back 918×516 76.3 KB

stellar controller 2 front 918×516 84.9 KB

stellar controller 2 front 918×516 84.9 KB

stellar controller 2 back 918×516 76.3 KB

stellar controller 2 back 918×516 76.3 KB

We would love to hear any feedback from the community and multiple members of Stellar Robotics are available for questions in this thread. If you would like to take off with your own creativity, links to the CAD model and the code are located in the document above. Be sure to post what you come up with here, we’d love to see it!

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: Is v2… comfortable? It looks a little painful to hold

posts.name: Andrew
posts.cooked: the angular design on the controller doesn’t really protrude much so while it might look like it would be poking into your hand it’s not really noticeable

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 5413 Alumni | Stellar Robotics Lead CAD Mentor

posts.custom_user_title: 5413 Alumni | Stellar Robotics Lead CAD Mentor

posts.name: Electra Lucky Norwood
posts.cooked: It is surprisingly smooth. Still has that 3D printed material feel to it, but it was printed on a Bambu A1 so it’s not as bad as it looks.

posts.name: Andrew
posts.cooked: here’s a quote from our driver which has had the most time with the controller “It’s actually quite comfortable. The controller does look like it has a lot of edges,  but they are all smooth and help a little bit with actually gripping the controller. Also, the ergonomics of where all the buttons are located are also very comfortable.”

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 5413 Alumni | Stellar Robotics Lead CAD Mentor

posts.custom_user_title: 5413 Alumni | Stellar Robotics Lead CAD Mentor

posts.cooked: We have a custom controller with 90 degree edges, and its been fine.

posts.name: Andrew
posts.cooked: I was unaware of anyone else doing a custom controller. I have heard about a lot of button panels but not hand held controllers. I’d love to hear more about yours and what kind of inputs you chose to include.
